stimulusHtml: Which of the following statements best describes a pattern evident on the map?

features.html:
• From southwest to east, the map shows the countries or regions surrounding the Indian Ocean, including:
    • Mozambique
    • Madagascar
    • Swahili Coast
    • Arabia
    • Persia
    • India
    • China
    • Sumatra
    • Borneo
    • Philippine Islands
    • Maluku Islands
  • The following features are also shown:
    • Trade routes
    • Area controlled by Shona monarchy
    • Gold mining region
    • Extent of Islam in 1500
  • In the area around Mozambique:
    • The only gold mining region on the map is near the city of Great Zimbabwe.
    • The area controlled by the Shona monarchy includes the gold mining region and the city of Great Zimbabwe.
    • Several trade routes are shown:
      • Some routes go to Madagascar.
      • Some routes go north to the Swahili Coast, Arabia, and Persia.
      • Some routes go northeast to India.
  • From northeast to southwest, the Extent of Islam in 1500:
    • Encompasses all of northeastern Africa and western Asia, including:
      • Arabia
      • Persia
      • most of India
    • Includes parts of the following countries on the eastern coast of Africa:
      • Swahili Coast
      • Mozambique
      • northern Madagascar
    • Includes parts of Sumatra and Melaka
  • Many trade routes are shown:
    • All routes are shipping routes.
    • Most routes pass between nearby ports. For example:
      • Routes along the Swahili Coast pass south along the coast to Mozambique and Madagascar and north to Arabia.
      • Routes near China pass between parts of China to the Philippines, Borneo, and Sumatra.
    • The network of routes is such that it would be possible to move from Great Zimbabwe in the southwest to the Maluku Islands in the east following only trade routes.

choicesHtml: Trans-Saharan commerce brought North African traders, scholars, and administrators to West Africa, introducing Islam to the region.
The Red Sea connected the Aksumite Empire to major maritime trade networks in the Mediterranean, linking it to the Roman Empire.
The coastal location of East Africa’s city-states linked Africa to Arab, Persian, Indian, and Chinese trading communities.
Portuguese and African trade increased the presence of Africans in Iberian port cities like Lisbon and Seville.
